policy.scope: cartoon and classical animation drawing/animation principles (non-software specific)
restrictions: Avoid studio marketing language; use discipline-standard terms

items.label: Squash and Stretch
items.definition: A principle of deforming forms to convey weight, elasticity, and impact while maintaining structural coherence.
items.extended: Used to make motion read clearly and to communicate material properties; deformation is calibrated to the style system and narrative register.

items.label: Anticipation
items.definition: A preparatory movement that precedes a main action to enhance clarity and perceived realism.
items.extended: Anticipation signals intent and direction, improving legibility in fast sequences and stylized motion systems.

items.label: Exaggeration
items.definition: Amplification of motion, form, or expression to enhance visual communication.
items.extended: Exaggeration supports legibility and affect by making intent and force visually explicit within a stylized system.

items.label: Staging
items.definition: Compositional organization that directs attention and clarifies narrative intent within a shot.
items.extended: Staging uses silhouette, contrast, and spatial arrangement to make actions readable under time constraints.

items.label: Follow-Through
items.definition: Continuation of motion in secondary parts after the primary action concludes.
items.extended: Follow-through supports material realism and dynamic continuity, particularly for hair, clothing, and flexible forms.

items.label: Timing and Spacing Coordination
items.definition: Coordinating duration and positional intervals to shape perceived weight and speed.
items.extended: Even with the same frame count, different spacing patterns can communicate distinct acceleration profiles and material cues.

items.label: Arcs
items.definition: Planning motion along curved paths to preserve naturalistic movement cues.
items.extended: Arcs improve perceived fluidity and reduce unintended stiffness in limb and body motion.

items.label: Secondary Action
items.definition: Supporting motion that complements the primary action without competing for focus.
items.extended: Secondary action reinforces character psychology and environmental interaction while preserving staging priorities.

items.label: Appeal (Design Readability)
items.definition: Designing forms and poses that remain clear and engaging under motion and time constraints.
items.extended: Appeal is often treated as a readability and coherence property rather than subjective decoration, tied to silhouette and proportion control.

source_entry_points.label: The Met — Heilbrunn Timeline (visual analysis entry)

items.label: Solid Drawing (Volume Control)
items.definition: Maintaining coherent volume and structure as forms rotate or deform.
items.extended: Volume control supports consistent identity and prevents unintended flattening across frames.

items.label: Follow-Through and Overlap
items.definition: Carrying motion into secondary parts to communicate inertia and material behavior.
items.extended: These cues support realism and rhythm, particularly for cloth, hair, and flexible appendages.

items.label: Staging Clarity
items.definition: Arranging action so intent is readable at a glance.
items.extended: Staging clarity is achieved through silhouette, contrast, and spatial organization that guides attention reliably over time.
